review.title: Existential Rule Languages with Finite Chase: Complexity and Expressiveness
review.abstract: Finite chase, or alternatively chase termination, is an important condition to ensure the decidability of existential rule languages. In the past few years, a number of rule languages with finite chase have been studied. In this work, we propose a novel approach for classifying the rule languages with finite chase. Using this approach, a family of decidable rule languages, which extend the existing languages with the finite chase property, are naturally defined. We then study the complexity of these languages. Although all of them are tractable for data complexity, we show that their combined complexity can be arbitrarily high. Furthermore, we prove that all the rule languages with finite chase that extend the weakly acyclic language are of the same expressiveness as the weakly acyclic one, while rule languages with higher combined complexity are in general more succinct than those with lower combined complexity.

sections.heading: Concluding Remarks
sections.text: Rather than looking at specific rule languages, as is the case with most current work on this topic, we have defined a family of rule languages based on a new concept called δ-boundedness, from which the general complexity and expression characteristics of these languages have been provided. Our study on this topic could be pursued in several directions. An interesting but challenging future work is the study of disjunctive existential rule languages. It is important to find out whether our approach can be expanded to identify decision-making disjunctive existential rule languages and to characterize relevant complexity and expression characteristics. Results on this aspect could significantly improve our current understanding of ontological reasoning with disjunctive existential rules (Alviano et al. 2012; Bourhis, Morak and Pieris 2013).
